questions.explanation:
Aspect Description
Type Exocrine gland
Secretion Sebum 
Secretion Process Holocrine secretion (cell disintegration)
Function - Lubricates and waterproofs skin and hair
  - Protects skin from external factors
  - Helps prevent dehydration of skin
  - Maintains suppleness of hair and skin

Control Influenced by hormones (androgens)
Common Disorders Acne, sebaceous cysts, seborrheic dermatitis

Which of the following Pulmonary function changes is not seen in emphysema?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Emphysema is a disease characterized by dilation of the alveolar spaces and destruction of the alveolar walls.
  • ↳ With their loss, much of the lung's elastic recoil is also lost.
  • ↳ To perform spirometry, the patient takes the biggest breath possible and blows it out as fast as possible. This is called a forced exhalation maneuver.
  • ↳ During this procedure, the total volume of air the patient can exhale in one breath is me asured; this is the FVC.
  • ↳ The amount of air that the patient can exhale in the first second is also measured; this is the FEV 1 .
  • ↳ Each is measured in litre and is reported as a per cent pre dicted for that pa ti ent.
  • ↳ The per cent predicted is based on reference values that consider the patient's age, sex and race.
  • ↳ The FVC is a measure of the amount of air the lungs hold. The FEV 1 is a measure of how easily air flows through the lungs.
  • ↳ FEV 1 and FVC = reduced in emphysema.
  • ↳ Compliance of the lung in emphysema is significantly above normal; the lung becomes easy to distend but empties slowly.
  • ↳ This results in a chronically overinflated lung (high total lung capacity, functional residual capacity, and residual volume), which lessens the curvature of the diaphragm, making it less efficient in generating even the small swings in pleural pressure necessary for breathing.
  • ↳ Pulmonary function tests on a patient with emphysema will reveal a compromised expiratory flow (due to their low lung recoil), including a low FEV1, FVC, and FEV1/FVC ratio.
  • ↳ Option A: ↑ TLC
  • ↳ Emphysema increases airway resistance & work of breathing difficulty in exhaling air due to compression of bronchioles leading to the eventual increase of TLC (barrel chest).
  • ↳ Emphysema increases airway resistance & work of breathing difficulty in exhaling air due to compression of bronchioles leading to the eventual increase of TLC (barrel chest).
  • ↳ Option B: ↑ RV
  • ↳ Emphysema increases airway resistance & work of breathing difficulty in exhaling air due to compression of bronchioles, leading to an eventual increase in RV .
  • ↳ Emphysema increases airway resistance & work of breathing difficulty in exhaling air due to compression of bronchioles, leading to an eventual increase in RV .
  • ↳ Option D: ↑ ΔV/ΔP
  • ↳ Destruction of alveolar septa leads to an increase in compliance (C= ΔV/ΔP)
  • ↳ Destruction of alveolar septa leads to an increase in compliance (C= ΔV/ΔP)

    • Obstructive vs. Restrictive Lung Disease

     

    Obstructive

    Restrictive

    Characteristics

    Limitation of airflow due to partial or complete obstruction

    Reduced expansion of lung parenchyma accompanied by decreased total Lung capacity

    • Emphysema

    Total Lung capacity

    Normal

    Normal

    Reduced

    Decreased

    Normal or reduced

    FEV1/FVC ratio

    <0.8

questions.text: Which substance enhances the sensitivity of pain receptors but does not directly excite them?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning Objective
  • ➤ Prostaglandins & substance P are believed to enhance the sensitivity of pain receptors but do not actually excite them . Some of the chemicals that excite the chemical type of pain receptors include bradykinin, serotonin, histamine, potassium ions, acids, acetylcholine, and proteolytic enzymes. In addition, prostaglandins enhance the sensitivity of pain endings but do not directly excite them . Bradykinin: Dilates the blood vessels and decreases the blood pressure. It is considered a potent vasodilator. Increases the blood flow throughout the body by its vasodilator action. Increases permeability of capillaries during inflammatory conditions, resulting in edema in the affected area. Stimulates pain receptors. Causes contraction of extravascular smooth muscles, especially smooth muscles of the intestine. Serotonin: Is an inhibitory substance. Inhibits impulses of pain sensation in the posterior grey horn of the spinal cord. Causes mood depression and induces sleep. Causes vasoconstriction.

Causes contraction of extravascular smooth muscles, especially smooth muscles of the intestine.

Lloyd & Hunt

Function

High susceptibility to

A-alpha

Pressure

Pressure

Hypoxia

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of bilateral flank pain for one day. He is a known case of sarcoidosis . questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the office because of weakness in both legs for a day. Examination shows facial flushing, a systolic blood pressure range of 70-160 mm Hg, profuse diaphoresis, and bilateral facial paralysis. The laboratory values are found to be haemoglobin of 11.2 g/dL, white blood cell count of 4.9 × 10 3 /µL, platelet count of 118 × 10 3 /µL, C-reactive protein of 4.98 mg/dL, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 35 mm/hour. questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient who has had HIV for 2 years and has a CD4 count of 150 cells//µL presents with the complaint of fatigue, weight loss, and cough for several days. He is also complaining of chest tightness on breathing. The patient says that the symptoms are getting worse every day. The doctor ordered sputum microscopy. The Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stain of his sample showed black-coloured cysts, as shown in the image below. Select the true statement about the pathogen causing the above-mentioned disease as shown in the image.

options.label: B
options.text: Ampicillin is the drug of choice

options.label: C
options.text: Occurs in patients with CD4+ count 400/µL

questions.explanation:
Microorganism Pneumocystis jirovecii
Classification Fungus (formerly classified as a protozoan)
Infection Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP), an opportunistic infection affecting the lungs in immunocompromised individuals
Transmission Likely via airborne route
Predisposing Factors - HIV/AIDS- Organ transplantation- Immunosuppressive therapy- Certain malignancies
Clinical Presentation - Dry cough
- Shortness of breath
- Fever
- Chest discomfort
Diagnosis - Chest X-ray or CT scan- Microscopic examination of respiratory specimens- PCR testing
Treatment Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is the primary treatment
Prophylaxis Recommended for individuals at high risk (e.g., HIV patients with low CD4 counts)
Prevention - Antiretroviral therapy for HIV/AIDS patients- Prophylactic antibiotics in high-risk patients
Epidemiology Common among immunocompromised individuals, especially those with HIV/AIDS

questions.explanation:
NEUROFIBROMATOSIS TYPE 1

 

 NEUROFIBROMATOSIS TYPE 2

 
Autosomal dominant with variable penetrance

 

 Autosomal dominant with full penetrance

 
Incidence- 1 in 2600-3000

 

 Incidence- 1 in 25000-40000

 
NF1 gene on chromosome 17q11.2 encodes neurofibromin, a guanosine triphosphatase (GTPase)-activating protein (GAP) that modulates signaling through the RAS pathway

 

 NF2 gene on 22q encodes a cytoskeletal protein, merlin (moesin, ezrin, radixin-like protein) that functions as a tumor suppressor

 
Characterized by neurofibromas, plexiform neurofibromas, optic nerve gliomas, astrocytomas, meningiomas

 

 characterized by bilateral vestibular schwannomas in >90% of patients, multiple meningiomas, spinal ependymomas, and astrocytomas

questions.text: What is the reason for the increased bilirubin level in prehepatic jaundice?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased bilirubin production in the liver.

options.label: C
options.text: Bilirubin cannot be excreted from the liver.

options.label: D
options.text: Increased hemolysis of red blood cells.

questions.correct_answer: D. Increased hemolysis of red blood cells.
questions.explanation:
Type of Jaundice Causes Characteristics
Prehepatic Jaundice - Hemolysis (excessive breakdown of red blood cells) - Gilbert's syndrome (a genetic condition affecting bilirubin processing) - Increased unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin levels in the blood - Normal liver function
Hepatic Jaundice - Liver diseases (e.g., hepatitis, cirrhosis) - Medications/toxins that affect the liver - Infections - Alcoholic liver disease - Both unconjugated (indirect) and conjugated (direct) bilirubin levels may be elevated in the blood - Impaired liver function
Posthepatic Jaundice - Bile duct obstruction (e.g., gallstones, tumors, biliary atresia) - Pancreatic cancer - Choledocholithiasis (gallstones in the common bile duct) - Elevated conjugated (direct) bilirubin levels in the blood - Bile flow obstruction from the liver to the intestines

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presented to the OPD with a long-standing history of dysphagia and oral ulcers . He also gave a history of tobacco and alcohol consumption over the last 20 years . Now he has developed a whitish patch over the tongue , and there is painful opening of the mouth. On examination, there was cervical lymphadenopathy , and a hard lump was found on the underside of the oral cavity. Which of the following is a major risk factor for oral cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: Hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis are seen in Leukoplakia

options.label: B
options.text: Speckled erythroplakia is having low er risk than erythroplakia

options.label: C
options.text: Erythroplakia lesions with moderate to severe dysplasia should be excised

options.label: D
options.text: Leukoplakia is most commonly found on the soft palate and tonsillar pillars

questions.correct_answer: A. Hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis are seen in Leukoplakia
questions.explanation:
Leukoplakia Erythroplakia
  • White keratotic plaque or patch that cannot be rubbed off and cannot be given another diagnostic name
  • Risk factors: Smoking, alcohol, ill-fitting dentures, jagged tooth.
  • Key pathologic features: Hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, acanthosis.
  • In most cases, lesions regress spontaneously after stopping alcohol or tobacco consumption or correction of an underlying cause
  • Baseline biopsy should be done.
  • Lesions with moderate to severe dysplasia should be excised
  • Oral Leukoplakia has a low potential for malignancy.
  • Red mucosal plaque, most commonly found on the soft palate and tonsillar pillars.
  • Does not arise from an obvious mechanical or inflammatory cause.
  • Cannot be ascribed to another clinical or pathological condition.
  • Key pathologic features: severe cellular dysplasia
  • Because of increased malignant potential, all erythroplakia lesions must be biopsied.
  • Higher risk (17 times) of malignant transformation than Leukoplakia.

questions.explanation:
Anatomic landmark Description
Piriform sinus Trumpet players, manual labourers, and singers are prone to develop piriform sinus perforations.
Killian triangle Pharyngoesophageal diverticula occur here, and inadvertent cannulation of the diverticulum results in perforation.
Cricopharyngeous muscle Most common site of iatrogenic perforation.
Aortic arch/bronchus Esophagus is in direct contact with the aortic arch and bronchus, which both create a small indentation on the esophagram.
Gastroesophageal junction Most common site of perforation in Boerhaave’s syndrome.

Esophageal perforation
Iatrogenic Spontaneous
  • Most common type(60%)
  • Caused by endoscopy
  • The most common site is the cervical esophagus (cricopharyngeal area)
  • Esophageal rupture after vomiting
  • Most common site: the left posterolateral side of the distal esophagus

questions.text: What is the first-line treatment for a 60-year-old male with end-stage renal failure with severe hyperkalemia-induced ventricular tachycardia following DC shock?
questions.explanation:
Mechanism

Treatment

Indication

Notes

Antagonize cardiac activity
  • 10% calcium chloride (10 ml) or calcium gluconate
  • K+ > 6.5 mEq/L, particularly with ECG changes
  • Onset of action within few minutes, duration 30 – 60 minutes

Intracellular potassium shift
  • Insulin 10 – 20 units (administered in 50 ml 50% glucose to avoid hypoglycaemia)
  • Beta-2 agonists (nebulized albuterol 2.5 mg)
  • Hyperventilation
  • NaHCO31 mEq/Kg
  • K+ > 6.5 mEq/L
  • Onset within 10 – 20 minutes, duration 4 -6 hours
  • Induce K+ uptake by increasing extracellular pH

Increase renal excretion
  • Furosemide 20-40 mg IV
  • Volume expansion with isotonic saline
  • Fludrocortisone
  • Moderate to severe hyperkalemia
  • Increase Na+ delivery to cortical collecting duct and exchange with K+
  • Mineralocorticoid effect

Other routes of potassium elimination
  • Gastrointestinal resin exchange: Sodium polystyrene sulfonate (Kayexalate) 15-30 g PO or per rectal hemodialysis
  • Any sustained hyperkalemia
  • Moderate to severe hyperkalemia with oliguria

questions.explanation:
Condition Adenomyosis
Definition Adenomyosis is a benign gynecological condition in which endometrial tissue, which normally lines the uterus, grows into the muscular wall of the uterus (myometrium).
Symptoms - Heavy or prolonged menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia).
  - Severe menstrual cramps and pelvic pain.
  - Painful intercourse (dyspareunia).
  - Enlarged and tender uterus.
  - Pelvic pressure or a feeling of fullness.
Causes The exact cause of adenomyosis is not fully understood. It may be related to hormonal imbalances and inflammation.
Risk Factors - Age: Most commonly affects women in their 30s to 50s.
  - Childbirth: More common in women who have had multiple pregnancies.
  - Prior uterine surgery, such as a cesarean section or fibroid removal.
Diagnosis - Pelvic examination: Enlarged, tender uterus may be palpated.
  - Transvaginal ultrasound: May reveal thickened uterine walls and cystic areas within the myometrium.
  - Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI): Provides detailed images of the uterus, allowing better visualization of adenomyosis.
  - Hysteroscopy: A thin, lighted instrument is inserted through the cervix to examine the uterine cavity.
Treatment - Pain relief: Over-the-counter pain medications (NSAIDs) for mild pain.
  - Hormonal therapy: Birth control pills, hormonal IUDs, or GnRH agonists to control symptoms and reduce menstrual bleeding.
  - Uterine artery embolization: Minimally invasive procedure to reduce blood flow to the adenomyosis-affected areas.
  - Endometrial ablation: In some cases, if fertility is not a concern, this procedure may be considered to remove the endometrial lining and alleviate symptoms.
  - Hysterectomy: In severe cases or when other treatments fail, surgical removal of the uterus may be recommended.
Complications - Anemia: Due to heavy menstrual bleeding.
  - Infertility: Although adenomyosis itself may not always cause infertility, it can be associated with it, particularly in severe cases.
  - Impact on quality of life: Adenomyosis symptoms can significantly affect a woman's daily activities and emotional well-being.

questions.text: What is the appropriate statement regarding further treatment for a 58-year-old female with post-menopausal bleeding who is diagnosed with endometrial cancer and is on hormone replacement therapy for 1 year?

options.label: A
options.text: ET less than 5 mm requires no further evaluation

options.label: B
options.text: ET 5 to 10 mm confers no risk of endometrial cancer

options.label: C
options.text: No evaluation required in women on HRT

questions.correct_answer: A. ET less than 5 mm requires no further evaluation

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to Gynecology OPD with complaints of abdominal distention and pain over the previous 3 months. Her physical examination reveals an abdominal mass without shifting dullness and bilateral adnexal masses. Her digital rectal examination reveals the presence of induration in the rectal pouch. Her breast examination and recent mammogram are normal. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.correct_answer: A. Serous cystadenocarcinomas of both ovaries

questions.text: An Asian woman aged 35 years with delayed cycles and a history of primary infertility presented to the infertility clinic for an infertility workup. On laparoscopic examination, she has a normal uterus with bilateral enlarged ovaries and normal fallopian tubes; chromotubation shows blue dye spillage; however, she did not give a history of any previous pelvic infection. What is the most probable cause of patient this condition and infertility?

A 57-year-old woman presents to the gynaecology clinic complaining of vaginal bleeding and mild fever. She had a cessation of menstruation 5 years ago. A pelvic exam shows a normal cervix. Her pap smear done 1 month prior was normal. She has no other comorbidities. USG reveals an endometrial thickness of 1mm and atrophic ovaries. What is the most probable diagnosis?
What is true about the Organ of Rosenmuller in reproductive embryology and its associated pathologies?

options.label: A
options.text: Remnant of Mullerian duct in males

options.label: B
options.text: Consists of horizontal tubules in the mesovarium

options.label: C
options.text: Tubules are lined by columnar cells

options.label: D
options.text: Represents the cranial end of the Wolffian duct

questions.correct_answer: D. Represents the cranial end of the Wolffian duct

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to a fertility clinic with the inability to conceive f or 3 years. She and her husband live together and have been married for 4 years. They are not using any contraception at present and are sexually active. Her menses are at regular 28 day intervals. Her husband is a cyclist by profession. The initial tests that should be advised to this couple are?

options.label: B
options.text: Semen analysis, Tubal patency test, Ovulation test

options.label: D
options.text: Testicular biopsy, USG, Sperm penetration test

questions.correct_answer: B. Semen analysis, Tubal patency test, Ovulation test

questions.text: A 29-year-old nulliparous woman presents with the complaint of a mass descending per vaginum for three months. She says she's never been married and was sexually active two years ago with her boyfriend for a few months only. On pelvic examination, there is a descent of the uterus and cervix beyond the introitus. Which of the following is the most suitable procedure for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Peri/menopausal women Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair
Young women with completed family Manchester/ Fothergill
Young women with incomplete family Abdominal sling surgery
Very old/ unfit for surgery LeFort's operation
Pregnant/ delay surgery/ very early prolapse Pessary

questions.text: A radiologist performing an obstetric ultrasound visualizes the placenta and calls it Grade III. Placental grading on ultrasound is based on following criteria:-

<18 weeks

uniform echogenicity

smooth chorionic plate

18-29 weeks

Scattered echogenicities and subtle chorionic plate undulations
Grade II

30-38 weeks

Echogenic stippling at the basal plate
Grade III

≥ 39 weeks

Echogenic indentations extending from the chorionic plate to the basal plate which resemble cotyledons.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, who achieved pregnancy through in vitro fertilization (IVF) , undergoes a bedside transvaginal ultrasound at 7 weeks gestation. Time of cell division Chorionicity of placenta

>12th day Conjoined/Siamese twins, type of MCMA (Formation of embryonic plate occurs)

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal clinic at 33 weeks of gestation for a routine checkup. Her BP is 170/100 mmHg. Her lipid profile and cardiac evaluation are normal. She never had raised BP in the past and has no family history of hypertension. Her urinalysis shows WBC 0-1/ HPF, albumin 2+, no glucosuria, and no pus cells. Which of the following is an expected renal change in this patient?

A primigravida is seen at 26 weeks, and an OGTT is advised. Her values are deranged, and she is started on a diabetic diet. She has no past or family history of diabetes. Which of the following is the best explanation for such a presentation?
questions.correct_answer: A. Increase in human placental lactogen

questions.text: The gestational form of diabetes in pregnancy usually occurs late compared with overt diabetes. This is the body's change in metabolism due to altering hormonal levels during pregnancy. All are consistent with diabetogenic effects of pregnancy except?

A 26-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, comes to the clinic at 32 weeks of gestation for a routine prenatal visit. She has felt normal fetal movements and has no abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, or fluid leakage. Physical examination is normal, and fundal height is appropriate for gestational age and her obstetrician examines the fetal head diameters abdominally. Which of the following is the shortest diameter of the fetal head?

A 25-year-old primigravida presents at the 37th week of gestation with complaints of low-grade fever followed by vesicular rashes on the body. Her previous vaccination status is unknown. Multinucleated giant cells are seen in microscopy of the vesicle. PCR confirms varicella-zoster virus. Which of the following is true regarding varicella-zoster virus in pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: No intervention for exposed seronegative mother

options.label: D
options.text: Immunoglobulins to be given to a neonate when the mother has varicella 5 days before delivery.

questions.correct_answer: D. Immunoglobulins to be given to a neonate when the mother has varicella 5 days before delivery.

questions.text: A primigravida at 10 weeks presents with fatigue, abdominal pain, shortness of breath, and fruity odour in her breath. A diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis is made. A history suggestive of which of the following must be elicited as a cause of her ketoacidosis?

A mother brings her 6-month-old boy for a regular check-up. She worries whether her baby's growth might be inadequate. His physical examination is unremarkable, weighing 6.4kg , and his length is 64cm . The boy was born at term gestation via uncomplicated vaginal delivery, and his birth weight was 3.8 kg. Postnatally, in which year of life is the maximum growth?

options.label: A
options.text: In the first year of life

options.label: B
options.text: In the second year of life

options.label: C
options.text: In the seventh year of life

questions.correct_answer: A. In the first year of life

  • 7 months

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman G3P2L2 presents to the hospital with complaints of vaginal bleeding for the last 2 hours . She is at 28 weeks of gestation. She delivered a preterm baby boy weighing 1200 grams, and the neonate was shifted to the NICU for further treatment. As the baby's lungs are not mature enough by this time , what would be the recommended dose of steroids given to the child to attain lung maturity ?

options.label: A
options.text: Injection Betamethasone 12 mg for two doses 12 hours apart

options.label: B
options.text: Injection Betamethasone 12 mg for two doses 24 hours apart

options.label: C
options.text: Injection Dexamethasone 6 mg for four doses 24 hours apart

options.label: D
options.text: Injection Dexamethasone 12 mg for two doses 12 hours apart

questions.correct_answer: B. Injection Betamethasone 12 mg for two doses 24 hours apart
questions.explanation: Correct option A :

questions.text: A 1-week-old baby girl is brought to the emergency room by her father due to yellowish discoloration of the skin and generalized swelling of the body . The symptoms started two days ago and progressed gradually. On further examination, there is evidence of hepatomegaly on USG. Labs reveal elevated unconjugated bilirubin and low RBC count . What is the most likely diagnosis?

CME is being conducted at a medical college, and all departments are supposed to present a seminar on topics related to maternal and neonatal care . The Department of Pediatrics presents a seminar on the benefits of breast milk . While giving the seminar, they have to inform them about the benefits of the higher lactose content of breast milk. Which of the following should they mention in the benefits ?

options.text: Helps in the deformation of galactocerebrosides

options.label: C

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy arrives at the emergency department with a fever and two days of breathing difficulties. His vital signs include a blood pressure of 105/60 mmHg, a pulse of 102 per minute , a respiratory rate of 26 per minute, and a temperature of 102oF . An arterial blood gas analysis reveals respiratory acidosis. What's the likely cause of the acid-base disturbance in this case?

A 10-year-old male child is admitted to a hospital for acute gastroenteritis . He had several episodes of diarrhea and vomiting . On examination, he has sunken eyes and dry oral mucosa. He is drowsy, and the skin pinch goes back very slowly. His current weight is 20 kg . He is now on fluid replenishment therapy. What is the daily maintenance fluid for this child?

questions.text: A 3-year-old female child is brought to the clinic by her mother with the complaint of speech development problems; she states that her sister, who is also a doctor, has suggested that her baby might have a hearing problem which is leading to pathological speech development. The ENT doctor suggests BERA to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following statement is correct about BERA? 1) Study of electric waves produced along the neural pathway of sound 2) It is an objective test 3) Screening test for neonatal deafness 4) Confirmatory test for neonatal deafness

An 8-year- girl was brought to the emergency department by her mother because of fever and pain in the left ear for 2 days. The mother says her daughter had three episodes of the same symptoms that resolved with antibiotics during the past year. The patient has a history of pulsatile ear discharge. She has no known medication allergies. W hat will be the most probable diagnosis?

A 4-year-old child has been brought to the pediatrician with nasal obstruction for the last 3 days. It is noted that the child is also bleeding from the same side of the nose. On examination, there is foul-smelling nasal discharge and a mass inside the nose. In which of the following conditions, foul-smelling discharge is not the key a finding?

A 30-year-old female presents to the clinic due to pain in her throat and upper neck for 2 weeks. The pain is sudden in onset, sharp radiates to the right ear, and gets aggravated on swallowing. The lateral skull x-ray of the patient is shown below: What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A 2-month child is brought to the hospital with noisy breathing since two weeks old. It gets worse when he is lying supine and gets relieved when the mother turns him to the prone position. The condition also aggravates on crying. Examination reveals inspiratory stridor. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. This increase in severity of inspiratory stridor in the supine position is associated with which of the following conditions?

A 70-year-old man presents to the physician's office with a complaint of hoarseness of voice for the past six months. He is a chronic smoker and has a 50-pack-year history of smoking. On physical examination, neck lymph nodes are not palpable; however, laryngoscopy shows a large, infiltrating, fungating, soft papillary lesion. Two biopsies taken from the lesion proper show be­nign appearing papillomatosis with hyperkeratosis and acanthosis infiltrating the subjacent tissues. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old female presents to the hospital with a tender swelling at the angle of the jaw for 3 days. On examination, there is restricted jaw mobility and medial displacement of the affected tonsil. No membranous covering or discharging sinus is seen around the tonsils. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the given clinical condition?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a case of parapharyngeal abscess

options.label: B
options.text: The female gender is predictive of high-risk cases

options.label: C
options.text: IV antibiotics are necessary for the treatment

options.label: D
options.text: An intraoral incision is given for incision and drainage

questions.correct_answer: D. An intraoral incision is given for incision and drainage

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of unilateral nasal obstruction and nasal discharge. He had a history of rhinosinusitis two weeks ago. An anterior rhinoscopy revealed a large shiny mass protruding from the anterior nares. Posterior rhinoscopy showed the same mass protruding from the posterior choanae. The child was diagnosed with an antrochoanal polyp. What is the current treatment of choice for a large antrochoanal polyp in this 10-year-old child?
The lens of the human eye in Latin is called aquula, which means a little stream of aqua/water or crystalline lens. Which of the following is a true statement regarding the eye's lens?

The neural crest is a highly migratory multipotent cell population that forms at the interface between the neuroepithelium and the prospective epidermis of a developing embryo. They result in the formation of various structures within the eye. Which of the following is a neuroectodermal derivative?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Sphincter pu

Embryonic layers

Structures derived

Surface ectoderm
  • The crystalline lens
  • Epithelium of the cornea
  • Epithelium of the conjunctiva
  • Lacrimal gland
  • Epithelium of eyelids and its derivatives viz., cilia, tarsal glands, and conjunctival glands.
  • Epithelium lining the lacrimal apparatus.

Neural ectoderm
  • Retina with its pigment epithelium
  • Epithelial layers of the ciliary body
  • Epithelial layers of the iris
  • Sphincter and dilator pupillae muscles
  • Optic nerve (neuroglia and nervous elements only)
  • Melanocytes
  • Secondary vitreous
  • Ciliary zonules (tertiary vitreous)

Associated paraxial mesenchyme
  • The choroid, iris, ciliary vessels, central retinal artery, and other vessels are blood vessels.
  • Primary vitreous
  • Substantia propria, Descemet's membrane, and endothelium of the cornea
  • The sclera
  • Stroma of iris
  • Ciliary muscle
  • Sheaths of the optic nerve
  • Extraocular muscles
  • Fat, ligaments, and other connective tissue structures of the orbit

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of bilateral prominence and bulging of the eyes for 2 weeks. He is a known case of hypothyroidism. He is otherwise vitally stable. On examination, there is bilateral exophthalmos and proptosis with marked chemosis but without any diplopia. The MRI of the eyes of the patient is done, which is shown in the image below, which reveals the Coca-cola bottle sign. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A cataract is an opacity in the clear lens that leads to blurry vision. The most common type of cataract is senile cataract. Cataracts, however, are also formed in certain metabolic and congenital disorders. Which of the following leads to a rosette-shaped cataract?

A 22-year-old obese man presented with the features of anterior uveitis in the left eye after a penetrating injury to his left eye, for which oral and topical steroids were prescribed. He developed sympathetic ophthalmitis (SO) signs in his right eye after a certain period. On general examination, the patient had a pulse rate of 78/min, blood pressure of 114/68 mm Hg, respiratory rate of 16/min, and was afebrile. Which of the following is the feature of s ympathetic ophthalmitis?

options.label: A
options.text: Accommodation failure in the good eye.

options.label: B
options.text: Presents between 2 days- 2 weeks after injury.

options.label: C
options.text: Retrolental flare is the late sign.

options.label: D
options.text: Dalen Fuchs nodules are seen on the choroid.

questions.correct_answer: D. Dalen Fuchs nodules are seen on the choroid.

questions.text: The human eye is a specialized sense organ capable of receiving visual images, which are then carried to the brain. Intraocular pressure (IOP) is the pressure in your eyes. When that pressure is higher than normal, it causes ocular hypertension. While ocular hypertension isn't an eye disease in itself, it is an indication that you could develop glaucoma. Your eye pressure is measured in millimetres of mercury, expressed as mm Hg. The Ophthalmic investigation shown in the image below is?
A patient presented with the symptoms of ocular irritation, foreign body sensation and diminution of vision. A band-shaped white horizontal opacity can be seen in his eyes. Identify the eye disorder.
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Band-shaped keratopath

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents to the clinic with the complaint of foreign body sensation in the eye for the past few weeks. She wears contact lenses. The examination shows the following findings. This condition occurs due to : Which of the following is true about the given condition?

A 52-year-old male presents with bullae formation over the trunk and buccal mucosa. On examination, bullae are flaccid and slight rubbing of the skin results in exfoliation of the outermost layer. Biopsy of skin lesion shows acanthocytes and row of tombstone appearance. Which of the following is the most common variant of the patient’s condition?

A 35-year-old female visits the clinic complaining of a lesion on the upper lip. The intra-oral exam shows a pinkish nodule with irregular edges, a flat surface, and soft consistency. Histopathological examination of the lesion shows solitary rounded, amorphous, eosinophilic masses of basement membrane material at the dermo-epidermal junction. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?

A 34-year-old male presents in the clinic with the complaint of rash for the past 3 days. Examination reveals numerous hypopigmented, macular, scaly lesions over the trunk, as shown in the picture. Which of the following statements is most likely true regarding this rash?

options.label: B
options.text: Selenium sulfide is used for the treatment

options.label: C
options.text: Wood's lamp examination shows branching septate hyphae

options.label: D
options.text: The causative organism also causes vulvovaginitis

questions.correct_answer: B. Selenium sulfide is used for the treatment

questions.text: A 15-years-old boy is brought to the hospital with the complaint of a skin lesion on his left leg. Examination shows asymmetric skin lesions characterized by erythematous plaques with elevated external borders and a hypochromic center. There is sensory loss over the lesion. Several satellite lesions are seen. A photograph of the lesion is given below: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Tuberculoid Borderline tuberculoid Mid Borderline Borderline Lepromatous
Number of skin lesions Single or up to 3 Multiple (3 to 10) Multiple (10-20) Multiple (>30)
Size in diameter >10cm Variable in size Variable in size  2-3 cm
Surface and Character Well-defined, hypopigmented plaque with dry, hairless, and usually scaly surface and moderately raised granular margins A distinct, erythematous hypochromic lesion with a dry surface and raised well-defined margins with satellite lesions Variable shaped and sized asymmetric papule, plaque, circinate lesions, and nodule Irregular, erythematous, infiltrated bands around anaesthetic central "immune" area; inner margins of lesion are better defined than the outer margins, i.e., punched out "Swiss cheese appearance." Irregularly shaped erythematous, slightly infiltrated patches with an area of apparently normal skin in between the shiny copper-coloured surface
Anaesthesia Completely anaesthetic surface Anaesthetic (less intense than tuberculoid type) Slightly diminished Slightly diminished
AFB Negative Scanty bacilli in lesions High density Plenty
